entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 31 at 3:50AM PDT until October 31 at 5:00PM PDT by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow for elevations above 6000 feet. Additional snow accumulations of 2-4 inches, locally higher at peaks and higher elevations. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Burney Basin / Eastern Shasta County, West Slope Northern Sierra Nevada, and Western Plumas County/Lassen Park Counties.
* WHEN...Until 5 PM PDT this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Snow covered roads, chain controls and travel delays possible. The hazardous conditions could impact the Thursday morning and evening commutes. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Heaviest snowfall is expected through Thursday afternoon, then scattered snow showers will persist. A second wave of moisture and snow showers is forecast to move into the area Friday evening through Saturday and should bring slightly higher amounts. Chain controls are currently in effect for portions of I-80.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Burney Basin / Eastern Shasta County; Western Plumas County/Lassen Park; West Slope Northern Sierra Nevada

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued October 31 at 3:38AM PDT until November 1 at 5:00PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
...EARLY SEASON SNOWFALL TO THE CASCADES THROUGH FRIDAY AFTERNOON...
.A cold front will bring a rapid onset of accumulating snow above 4000 feet this afternoon and evening. Precipitation will be more showery today, increasing in intensity tonight into Friday. Highest accumulations will be above 5000 feet and in the Linn and Lane County Cascades. Winds too will become gusty from the south tonight which will increase chances for blowing snow and reduced visibility.
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches above 4000 feet and 12 to 28 inches above 5000 feet.
* WHERE...Cascades of Lane County.
* WHEN...Until 5 PM PDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the Thursday morning and evening commutes.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cascades of Lane County

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM PDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued October 31 at 6:22AM AST until October 31 at 9:30AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
FFWSJU
The National Weather Service in San Juan has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Naguabo County in Puerto Rico...
* Until 930 AM AST.
* At 622 AM AST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Emergency management reported Rio Blanco out of their banks near Sector Pitina, and road PR-31 is now impassable. Between 1 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Emergency management reported.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Naguabo, Aguas Claras, Roosevelt Roads, Duque, Rio Blanco, Pena Pobre and Daguao.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Naguabo, PR

entry.title: Flood Watch issued October 31 at 5:27AM AST until November 2 at 8:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Puerto Rico, including Vieques and Culebra, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.
* WHEN...Through at least Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may be flooded. Storm drains and ditches may become clogged with debris. Extensive street flooding and flooding of creeks and rivers are possible. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Flooding rains observed overnight already saturated soils over NE Puerto Rico, Vieques, Culebra and the USVI. Expected additional rains will result in river and flash flooding,and mudslides.
- A series of mid-to-upper level troughs and above-normal moisture from a nearly stationary front will create ideal conditions for thunderstorm development over the next few days, with the most intense and frequent activity expected through at least Saturday morning. Recent and expected moderate to heavy rain pulses will likely saturate soils before the peak unsettled weather period, setting the scenario for significant excessive rainfall hazard risks. Rainfall totals during this period are expected to range from 3 to 6 inches, with locally higher amounts of 8 to 10 inches across northern and eastern Puerto Rico, Vieques, Culebra, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Elsewhere, expect rainfall amounts around 1 to 2 inches.
Due to the high likelihood that any extended period of moderate to heavy rainfall will lead to flash flooding, sudden river surgespotentially causing some rivers to exceed flood-stage levelsand mudslides in areas with steep terrain, a Flash Flood Watch has been issued.
Although uncertainties are present, unsettled weather conditions will likely continue from Sunday into early next week. Residents and visitors, especially those in flood-prone areas or planning outdoor activities in the coming days, are advised to closely monitor the latest weather forecasts.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: San Juan and Vicinity; Northeast; Southeast; Eastern Interior; North Central; Central Interior; Ponce and Vicinity; Northwest; Western Interior; Mayaguez and Vicinity; Southwest; Culebra; Vieques; St.Thomas...St. John.. and Adjacent Islands; St Croix

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued October 31 at 2:48AM CDT until October 31 at 3:00PM CDT by NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN
entry.summary:
...RAIN EXPECTED TO TURN TO HEAVY SNOW THIS MORNING WITH TRAVEL IMPACTS LIKELY...
.Widespread rain is developing early this morning and will become heavy at times. As colder air begins to move in this morning, the rain will transition to heavy snow from west to east with snowfall rates of an inch per hour at times into early afternoon. A few embedded thunderstorms are also possible, which could enhance snow rates further. Total accumulations of 2 to 4 inches are likely in a narrow band from just north of Mankato through most of the Twin Cities metro area, to northwest Wisconsin. Locally higher totals are possible if the heaviest bands remain nearly stationary. In addition, northwest winds 15 to 20 mph with gusts as high as 30 or 35 mph could aid in deteriorating travel conditions.
A Winter Weather Advisory is in effect from mid morning through mid afternoon.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 2 and 4 inches. Locally higher totals are possible.
* WHERE...McLeod, Sherburne, Sibley, Wright, Carver, and Isanti Counties.
* WHEN...From 8 AM this morning to 3 PM CDT this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Thursday morning commute.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 31 at 2:53PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
This is the final Special Weather Statement regarding JTWC's Invest 90W. Invest 90W is now centered to the west-southwest of Pohnpei near 6.5N 155.9E, with maximum sustained winds of 15 to 20 mph. 90W has become difficult to identify in recent Himawari visible satellite imagery, with the location of the low-level circulation center unclear. Invest 90W may become better organized over the next day or so, but is expected to move further away from Pohnpei to the west, before eventually tracking northwest. Although this will be the last statement regarding 90W and the threat is diminishing, locally heavy showers and gusty winds will remain possible across the region tonight as a broad low-pressure trough sits nearby.
Residents across Pohnpei State should continue to monitor local weather forecasts the next couple of days from the National Weather Service in Guam, and for additional information from your local Weather Service Office and emergency management. Visit weather.gov/gum/PublicForecasts for the latest weather information from the National Weather Service.
DeCou
entry.cap:areaDesc: Pohnpei

cap:parameter.value: INVEST 90W IS MOVING AWAY...THREAT FROM LOCALLY HEAVY SHOWERS AND GUSTY WINDS HAS DIMINISHED

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued October 30 at 2:11PM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
entry.summary: A chilly morning is expected for southwest and south-central New Mexico Thursday morning with the coolest air of the season so far. Dry air, light winds, and clear skies will set the stage for rapid cooling starting after midnight. This pattern will allow sheltered, low-lying areas to cool to near or just below the freezing mark early in the morning before warming again shortly after sunrise. Agricultural interests in known cold regions should take precautions to protect plants from freezing temperatures.

Withlacoochee River At Croom affecting Sumter and Pasco Counties.
Withlacoochee At SR 200 Holder affecting Citrus County.
Withlacoochee At US 301 Trilby affecting Hernando and Pasco Counties.
Cypress Creek At SR 54 Worthington Gardens affecting Pasco County.
Peace River At Bartow affecting Polk County.
For the Withlacoochee...including US 301 Trilby, Croom, SR 200 Holder, US 41 Dunnellon...Major flooding is forecast. For the Cypress Creek...including SR 54 Worthington Gardens...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Peace...including Bartow, Zolfo Springs at SR 17, Arcadia at SR 70...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Cypress Creek at SR 54 Worthington Gardens.
* WHEN...Until early Friday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, Flooding begins at the recreation area on State Road 54.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 8.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 8.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:00 AM EDT Wednesday was 10.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage Friday morning and continue falling to 7.7 feet Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 8.6 feet on 09/13/1982. - https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
